causes: Ivan IV of Russia sought access to Baltic trade routes.
Livonian Order weakened by internal struggles and financial problems.
Sweden & Poland-Lithuania wanted to block Russian expansion.
events_leading_up_to_war: Moscow launched an invasion of Livonia in 1558.
Livonian Order suffered early defeats and fragmented.
Poland, Sweden, and Denmark entered the war to divide Livonia among themselves.

result.general: Livonian Order dissolved; territories divided among Poland-Lithuania, Sweden, and Denmark.
result.treaty: Truce of Yam-Zapolsky (1582) between Russia & Poland; Treaty of Plussa (1583) between Russia & Sweden.
result.territorial_changes: Livonia split between Poland-Lithuania and Sweden, Russia lost most conquests.

allies: Livonian nobles defecting from the Order

Russia.dead: Tens of thousands, including famine losses
Russia.territorial_loss: Lost Livonia, kept some border forts

Poland_Lithuania.territorial_gain: Gained control of much of Livonia

major_battles.name: Siege of Narva
major_battles.description: Russia captured the Livonian city of Narva in an early offensive.

major_battles.name: Battle of Wenden
major_battles.description: A joint Polish-Swedish force crushed Russian troops in Livonia.

major_battles.name: Siege of Pskov
major_battles.description: Poland besieged the Russian city of Pskov; Russia barely held out, leading to peace negotiations.

texts.name: Ivan the Terrible’s war letters
texts.details: Documents detailing Ivan IV's strategy & conflicts with Livonia.

texts.name: Livonian Order Records
texts.details: Final records of the Livonian Order before its collapse.

archaeological_evidence.description: Castles destroyed during Russian and Swedish campaigns.
Artifacts from the Battle of Wenden, including weapons and armor.

political: Livonian Order dissolved, marking the end of Baltic crusader states.
Russia's expansion into the Baltic was blocked for over a century.
Poland and Sweden gained influence in the region.
long_term_effects: Set the stage for the Polish-Swedish wars over the Baltic.
Russia refocused on internal reforms and future European conflicts.

military: Demonstrated the weakness of medieval knightly orders against gunpowder armies.
Introduced modern siege tactics and early use of field artillery in the Baltic.
political: Marked a shift in Baltic power from religious orders to emerging nation-states.
Led to lasting Polish-Russian and Swedish-Russian rivalries.
cultural: Ended German knightly rule over the Baltic, paving the way for local governance.
Strengthened Polish and Swedish identities as Baltic powers.
